body.p:
Hopkinsville April 11th 1861.
Gov B Magoffin
Dear Sir

Johnathan Greer of was covicted at the last term of the Christian Circuit Court of manslauter and sentenced to the Penitentiary for the term of five years. Mr Greer is an old and rather infirm man sixty five years old. He has always borne a the character of a peaceable orderly citizen and never has been involved in difficulties or quarrels. Some year or two ago a daughter of Mr Greer married a trifling deseputed man who soon after abandoned her and the parties who were involved in the difficulty when Greer killed Ferrill slandered this daughter and justified the conduct of her husband by alledging infidelity on her part. I am informed that this lady is in every respect a prudent and worthy woman This very naturally produced bad feeling between the Greer family and the Ferrels and resulted finally in the killing of Ferrill by Greer. The circumstances attending this killing are set forth in other letters that will be handed you and are such as would naturally produce the greatest excitement in a Father and induce him in defence of the life of his child to take the life of his fellow man. I know well that the news
of Greer pardon would be received here with joy by almost every citizen of this county. The petition that will be handed you by Mr Bernard has been signed by the most respectable citizens of the county also by every member of the Bar & the Jury that covicted him I sincerely hope that after examining the facts connected with this case you will find it consistent with your duty to pardon this old man and thus releive the distress of his aged wife and worthy family

P S Since writing the above I understand that Mr Bernard will probably not be able to go to Frankfort and this letter & the petitions will be handed by Mr W H Clark a reliable gentleman in whose statements you may place implicit reliance.
